abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, with a highly likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impacts. Lessons reinforce the
            importance of a clear project design and quality at entry,
            as well as the significance of incorporating lessons from
            previous reform efforts. Likewise, commitment to, and
            ownership for the substance of the reforms, was key to the
            success of the reform program. In view of this, even in a
            hostile environment of permanent political and security
            turmoil, coupled with record high levels of unemployment,
            implementation of the ambitious and thorny reforms is
            possible, heavily dependent on effective leadership.
            Moreover, a daily and open dialogue allows counterparts to
            better understand the reform objectives. and the specific
            requirements of each of the components. Appropriate
            technical assistance (TA) greatly enhanced the reform
            process, provided by most donors in support of the
            financial, and enterprise sector reforms, and, the
            Government of Netherlands provided additional direct budget
            support for reforms. Nevertheless, certain reforms required
            appropriate social mitigation measures, particularly in
            dealing with enterprise restructuring, associated with
            liquidations and labor redundancies. Hence providing
            appropriate social support programs, namely through the
            Social Support Project, facilitated labor restructuring,
            provided severance payments, and fostered labor programs.
            Notwithstanding successes, the need for further, third wave
            reforms aimed at improving the overall investment climate,
            rule of law and governance, became obvious. This translates
            into an urgent need for reforms in the judiciary, as the
            deficiencies and deep systemic problems in the judicial
            sector, undermined the success of the reforms in the
            financial and enterprise sectors.
